did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle: Collection of James Fenimore Cooper, 1813-1844 and n.d.
did.physdesc: This collection consists of ca. 130 items.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use the microfilm of The Pathfinder manuscript unless permission to use the original is obtained from senior Special Collections staff.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers of James Fenimore Cooper, Accession #6245-a, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was deposited on 1960 April 16 and made a gift on July 1, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection is dated 1813-1850 and consists of correspondence with literary agents, publishers, friends, business associates, historians, and literary figures, relating to Cooper's career, legal and financial affairs, travels in Europe, family, and social life; manuscripts for The Pathfinder (1840), The Two Admirals (1842), and Mercedes of Castile (1840), partial manuscripts for The History of the Navy of the United States of America (1839), The Pilot (1823), Afloat and Ashore (1844), and The Water Witch (1831), and printer's manuscript for Home As Found (1838) with holograph corrections by Cooper; legal documents relating to Cooper's libel suit against James Watson Webb and to his land holdings in New York; correspondence of Cooper's daughter, Susan Fenimore Cooper, chiefly with William Branford Shubrick, relating to her father's death, his religious beliefs, and Cooper family genealogy; book reviews, prints, and engravings.

Cooper's correspondents include William Cullen Bryant, Richard Henry Dana, Rufus Wilmot Griswold, Jay family, and William Gilmore Simms. Susan Cooper's correspondents include Felix Octavius Darley, George Washington Greene, and Charles Mathews. Many of the letters have been published in The Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper, edited by James F. Beard (1960).

did.unittitle: Manuscripts
Article (in French) on Cooper by George Sand.
Title page The Chainbearer .
Four sketches by Bensell for The Deerslayer .
Four engravings of Cooper.
Leaf of The Headsman .
Fragments of The Headsman .
Preliminary draft of a report ("The Races") written for the New York Patriot .
Carey and Lea printed leaflet, 1 p., for (and some miscellaneous Ms booksellers' documents) Last of the Mohicans .
Preface to The Chain-bearer, or, The Littlepage manuscripts
Miscellaneous
Various notes concerning Cooper's novels
Typescript and photostats of 1850 preface to the collected Leather-Stocking Tales .
Typescript and photostat of introduction to the Spiller and Blackburn Bibliography.
The Wept of the Wish-Ton-Wish . Title page of the first printed edition, Florence, 1829. Biblioteca Nationale, Florence.
Carte dressee pour la lecture du Pilote Roman de J. Fenimore Cooper, par A. M. Perrot [1824?]
Page of Introduction to Naval History (The History of the Navy of the United States of America).
Fragment of manuscript on England - Notions of Americans .
Page from Oak Openings.

Fragment of page from Oak Openings

Page from Sea Lions .

scopecontent.p: comprises chapters 12, 13, and 14 (pp. 144-186 of volume I, 1831) and chapters 10, 16 (pp. 138-251 of volume II.), ca. 150 pages (in the hand of an amanuensis but filled with Cooper's autograph corrections and revisions)

scopecontent.p: Beautiful letter of condolence on the death of her brother, Peter Augustus Jay. Reflections on friendship and death. This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 363).

did.unittitle: Cooper to H. E. Parker 1843 May 27

scopecontent.p: Autograph. Re spelling of the name "Fenimore" and its provenance. This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 384).

did.unittitle: Cooper to John H. Sherburne 1843 May 28

scopecontent.p: Declining to deliver the eulogy for Commodore David Porter. This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 385).

did.unittitle: 1843 Jun 25 Cooper to [Horatio] Greenough

scopecontent.p: Funny. Re Greenough's naked statue of Washington. The mediocrity of American public opinion. This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 389).

did.unittitle: Cooper to W. G. Simms 1844 Jan 5

scopecontent.p: Vituperative letter about all his literary and personal woes. The decline of his career since Notions of the Americans . This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 436).

did.unittitle: Cooper to Richard Bentley(London publisher) 1844 Jan 9

scopecontent.p: Literary-financial. Miles Wallingford and Ned Myers . This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 440).

did.unittitle: Cooper to W. G. Simms 1844 Apr 22

scopecontent.p: Social.

did.unittitle: Cooper to Wiley and Putnam 1844 Sep 29

scopecontent.p: Afloat and Ashore conclusion ready to be announced. 3 lines only. This item is found in James Franklin Beard's Letters and Journals of James Fenimore Cooper vol. IV, (page 480).
